data.title: Macrae, John Kenneth (1873-1955)

data.text:
John Kenneth (“Ken”) Macrae was a lawyer. He lived at 1000 Gilford Street from 1917 to 1919 and at 1958 Barclay Street from 1920 to 1926.

Family Background

John Kenneth Macrae was born in Auckland, New Zealand, on January 29, 1873.

His parents were Farquhar Macrae (1837-1919) and Isabella Gillies (1858-1924).

Farquhar Macrae was the head of the Auckland Grammar School from 1871 to 1882.

While Ken Macrae was in New Zealand, he worked for Sargood, Son and Ewen, a firm of warehousemen and manufacturers.

To British Columbia

In 1892, Farquhar arrived in British Columbia, where he became the police magistrate in Victoria.

He was the police magistrate until about 1899. He then practiced law in Victoria for about four years..

Farquhar died in Sidney, British Columbia on December 15, 1919.

Ken’s mother, Isabella, died in Victoria on March 14, 1924.

To Vancouver

Ken Macrae arried in Victoria in October 1893,

After arriving in Victoria, he became a law student.

He became a lawyer in British Columbia in 1899.

To Yukon

Ken went to Dawson City in the Yukon, where he practiced law until about 1907. For a time, he was a partner with Arthur Gordon Smith, who lived at 1054 Denman Street from 1905 to 1909.

Marriage to Ellen King

On November 16, 1907, in Woodstock, Ontario, Ken married Helen (or Ellen) King.

Helen was born in Ingersoll, Ontario, on January 29, 1882. Her parents were William Scott King (1836-possibly 1887) and Ellen Jane Morrison (1839-1932).

Although it is not certain, William Scott King may have died in Toronto, Ontario in 1887.

Ellen Jane King died in West Vancouver, British Columbia on September 16, 1932.

Return to Vancouver

After the marriage, Ken and Ellen moved to Vancouver, where Ken established a law practice. They lived at the following addresses in Vancouver.

1646 Haro Street

1646 Haro Street was a house on the south side of Haro Street, about midway between Bidwell Street and Cardero Street.

Legal Description: District Lot 185, Block 57, Lot 4.

The photograph below shows the south side of the 1600 block of Haro Street. The house at 1646 Haro Street was outside the photograph, just to the left of the houses in the photograph. The number on the gate on the left is 1650.

1000 Gilford Street and 1958 Barclay Street

The Macrae family lived at 1000 Gilford Street from 1917 to 1919 and at 1958 Barclay Street from 1920 to 1926.

1926 Matthews Avenue

By 1927 the Macrae family was living at 1926 Matthews Avenue in Shaughnessy Heights.

The City of Vancouver issued a building permit for this house in 1921. The architects were Sharp and Thompson and the first owner was Christopher Arthur Mohan Cator (1881-1923), who was a financial agent with Waghorn Gwynn and Company Limited. (See Sharp, George Lister Thornton (1880-1974), Biographical Dictionary of Architects in Canada, 1800-1950; http://dictionaryofarchitectsincanada.org/node/1297: “Matthews Avenue, near Hosmer Avenue, for Christopher Cator, 1921 (dwgs. at Canadian Architectural Archives, Univ.of Calgary).)

The general contractor for the house was Samuel Nehamial McLeod (1868–1938).

Christopher Cator died on the Isle of Wight on December 6, 1923.

Later Life

Ken Macrae became a King’s Counsel in 1932. He was a president of both the Vancouver Bar Association and the Vancouver Board of Trade. He was a member of the Vancouver Club and the Canadian Club.

Ellen Macrae died in Vancouver on August 16, 1938.

Ken Macrae died in Vancouver on May 22, 1955.

Ken and Ellen had the following children.

Douglas Kenneth Macrae

Douglas Kenneth Macrae was born in Vancouver on August 31, 1913. He worked as a lawyer.

On April 13, 1940, in Vancouver, he married Marjorie Hazel Davenport.

Marjorie was born in London, Ontario, on April 15, 1916. Her parents were Ralph Pryce Davenport (1889-1970) and Edna Emily Cullingworth (1888-1971).

Douglas died in Vancouver on January 10, 1988.

Marjorie died in Vancouver on June 18, 1991.

William King Macrae

William King Macrae was born in Vancouver on May 4, 1920. He worked for the Downtown Parking Corporation in Vancouver.

On April 7, 1951, in Vancouver, he married Susan Georgia Alexandra de Wolf, who was often called “Georgia.” She was born on January 23, 1923. Her parents were Tempest Carroll MacPherson St. Etienne de Wolf (1894-1977) and Grace Kilpatrick Henderson (1896-1977).

Georgia obtained a B.A. from the University of British Columbia in 1949. She became a law librarian, first at the University of British Columbia and later at the University of Calgary

William died in Vancouver on August 28, 1977.

Georgia died in Calgary, Alberta on June 14, 2013.

Ken Macrae had the following siblings.

Isabella Lillie Macrae

Isabella Lillie Macrae was born in Auckland, New Zealand on April 18, 1868.

She never married.

She died in Vancouver on October 29, 1940.

Flora Mary Macrae

Flora Mary Macrae was born in Auckland, New Zealand on September 24, 1869.

She became a registered nurse.

She never married.

She died in Vancouver on October 28, 1950.

Ada Macrae

Ada Macrae was born in Auckland, New Zealand on September 24, 1872.

She trained as a nurse.

She never married.

She died in Victoria, British Columbia on March 28, 1915.

Ethel May Macrae.

Ethel May Macrae was born in Auckland, New Zealand on October 21, 1875.

She never married. She died in Vancouver on March 3, 1965.

Farquhar Alick Macrae

Farquhar Alick Macrae was born in Auckland, New Zealand on August 4, 1877.

In the 1890s, he travelled to British Columbia with his parents and other family members.

He was involved in many sports, including rowing, rugby and baseball. He was most well-known for his tennis skills.

By the late 1890s he was a clerk in the Nelson branch of the Bank of Montreal.

In 1903 the bank transferred him to Victoria, British Columbia.

In 1906, he moved to New Westminster, British Columbia.

On June 17, 1908, in New Westminster, he married Ethel Dyne Brymner. She was born on November 9, 1883, in Almonte, Lanark County, Ontario. Her parents were George Douglas Brymner (1857–1923) and Ann Elizabeth Harrison (1854–1937).

George Douglas Brymner died in New Westminster on July 14, 1923.

Ann Brymner died in New Westminster on November 23, 1937.

Farquhar and Ethel Macrae lived in Vancouver for the first year of their marriage.

In 1910, they moved to Victoria, British Columbia.

Farquhar later worked at the Bank of Montreal branch in Haney, British Columbia.

In 1912 he became the manager of the Bank of Montreal’s branch in North Vancouver.

In 1920 the bank transferred him to the branch at Granville Street and Nelson Street in Vancouver.

Farquhar died in North Vancouver on June 9, 1929, after collapsing during a tennis match.

Farquhar left his estate to his wife and children.

Ethel Macrae died in North Vancouver, British Columbia on August 20, 1943.

Farquhar and Ethel had two children.

Gertrude Elizabeth (“Betty”) Macrae

Gertrude Elizabeth Macrae was born in New Westminster, British Columbia on May 5, 1909.

She became a registered nurse.

She married William Thomson, who was a North Vancouver city firefighter. He was born in Stevenston, Ayrshire, Scotland on September 28, 1898. His parents were John Thomson (1870-1933) and Robertson Kerr (1869-1919)..

William had been married before, to Lillian Amy Locker. She was born in Sawley, Derbyshire, England on May 13, 1901. Her parents were Herbert William Locker (1874-1925) and Edith Gertrude Davies (1880-1971). William’s and Lillian’s marriage was in Edmonton, Alberta on June 30, 1924.

Lillian Thomson died in North Vancouver on October 20, 1940.

William Thomson died in North Vancouver, British Columbia on June 24, 1978.

Betty Thomson died in North Vancouver on March 23, 1980.

Dyne Brymner Macrae

Dyne Brymner Macrae was born in North Vancouver, British Columbia on November 27, 1913.

He worked as a bank clerk.

In August 1940 he became engaged to marry Mary Irene (Mae) Paton Young, who was a store clerk.

Mae was born in North Vancouver on August 18, 1912. Her parents were John Paton Young (1880-1931) and Jane (“Jeannie”) Lockhart Ralston (1882-1936).

John Paton Young was a plumbing contractor. He died in North Vancouver on November 15, 1931.

Jeanie Lockhart Young died in North Vancouver on September 6, 1936.

Dyne and Mae were married in Vancouver on September 18, 1940.

Mae Macrae died in Vancouver on October 31, 1941.

On March 14, 1949, in West Vancouver, British Columbia, Dyne married Evelyn Christine Hammer.

Evelyn Hammer was born on February 15, 1924, in Rossland, British Columbia. Her parents were Eric Olaf (or Olof) Hammer (1882-1963) and Johanna Karolina Mähler (also known as Hannah Caroline Mahler) (1887-1947).

Hannah Hammer died in Nelson, British Columbia on June 30, 1947.

Eric Hammer died in Vancouver on October 31, 1963.

Dyne Macrae died at White Rock, British Columbia on August 28, 1995.

Evelyn Macrae died in Langley, British Columbia on January 12, 2006.

Sources

Thanks to Aisla Tod for photographs and information relating to the Macrae family.

Mr. Macrae was a member of the Dawson bar for years. He left here on one of the last boats of the season.

Mr. and Mrs Macrae will tour the eastern cities, then spend a part of the winter in California. It has been reported they will settle in Vancouver. Another report received here from the coast is that they will make Fairbanks their home.”

“J.K. Macrae Funeral Rites Wednesday,” Vancouver Sun, May 24, 1955, page 2 [includes photograph of John K. Macrae]; https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=_UBlAAAAIBAJ&sjid=xYkNAAAAIBAJ&pg=1969%2C4687892:

“Funeral service for John Kenneth Macrae, of 1926 Matthews, lawyer in Dawson during gold rush years and a veteran on over half a century at the B.C. bar, will be held Wednesday in St. John’s (Shaughnessy) Anglican church at 2 p.m.

He was 82 when he died Sunday.

A native of Auckland, N.Z., Mr. Macrae was called to the B.C. bar in Victoria in 1899. He established an office in Vancouver in 1908 and was made a King’s Counsel in 1932.

A past president of the Vancouver Bar Association and of the Vancouver Board of Trade, he retired two years ago from the firm which he headed, Macrae, Montgomery, Macrae, Hill and Cunningham. He was also a director of the B.C. Cancer Foundation and member of the Vancouver Club and Canadian Club.

Survivors include two sons, Douglas K., a member of his father’s law firm, and William K., both of Vancouver, and one sister, Miss E. Macrae, also of Vancouver.

Funeral service will be conducted by Rev. A.M. Tendell [sic]. Cremation will follow.”

J.K. Macrae, pioneer barrister of B.C., dies, Vancouver Province, May 24, 1955, page 11 [includes photograph of John K. Macrae]:

John Kenneth Macrae, Q.C., veteran member of the legal profession in B.C. and former president of Vancouver Bar Association and Vancouver Board of Trade, died Sunday in General Hospital. He was 82.

He lived at 1926 Matthews.

Born in Auckland, New Zealand, Mr. Macrae moved to Victoria in 1894 where he was articled in law to the late Mr. Justice Gregory.

Called to the bar Feb. 1, 1899, he left soon after for Dawson, in the Yukon, and established a practice in the area then gripped by a gold rush. He left Dawson in 1908 for Vancouver where he helped found the firm of Ridley and Macrae.

When he retired in 1953, he was senior partner in the firm of Macrae, Montgomery, Macrae, Hill and Cunningham, one of the senior law firms in western Canada.

He was president of the Vancouver Board of Trade in 1924 and became a King’s Counsel in 1932. He was a director of the B.C. Cancer foundation and a member of the Vancouver Club and the Canadian Club.

Survivors include two sons, Douglas K. and William K. Macrae; one sister, Miss E.M. Macrae; and six grandchildren.

Funeral services will be held at 2 p.m. from St. John’s Shaughnessy Memorial Church with Rev. Alex McD. Trendell, rector, officiating. Burial will be in Mountain View Cemetery.”

Details of Funeral arrangements will be announced later by Center & Hanna.”

Georgia MACRAE, death notice, Calgary Herald, July 11 to July 13, 2013; http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/calgaryherald/obituary.aspx?n=georgia-macrae&pid=165781055&fhid=6135 : “MACRAE, Georgia (née Georgia Alexandra de Wolf); January 23, 1923 – June 14, 2013; Well dressed, well read, well travelled, well loved Georgia Macrae passed away peacefully on June 14, 2013 at her home in Calgary surrounded by her family. Known as Georgie to many and Dee to her oldest friends, she will be remembered for her wide-ranging interests, her ability to say exactly what she thought, and her insights and understanding of the people around her. She was born into one of the oldest Vancouver families; her grandfather was a Commissioner of the Yukon and BC Attorney General. She developed a love of opera, film and theatre from an early age, yet she was equally at ease discussing baseball, politics or cooking. A love of travel began with a solo trip to Europe in 1968. She subsequently visited every continent except Antarctica. She had a special love for London, having spent a year’s sabbatical there, and returned many times over the years. In between, she was always up for a road trip. She served as a WRCN radio operator in World War II, listening for German naval traffic. After the war, she earned a BA from UBC before marrying and having three children. When her children were in school, she returned to earn her Bachelor of Library Science. This led to her career as a law librarian, initially at UBC, then moving to Calgary in 1976 to open the U of C law library, where she worked until her retirement in 1986. She is survived by her three sons Stephen, Bruce (Angela) and Douglas (Vivianne), and five grandchildren, James, Lane, Teal, Philippa and Billie. At her request there will be no formal service. A celebration of her life is planned at East Coulee, Alberta where she spent many happy days. “Sprinkle me around and have a vodka”. Thanks, Mum – Jeopardy won’t be the same without you! : Funeral Home: McInnis & Holloway Funeral Home – Calgary; 5008 ELBOW DRIVE SOUTHWEST Calgary, AB T2S 2L5; (403) 243-8200.

John Anthony St. Etienne de WOLF; death notice, Vancouver Sun, May 31, 2003; [CAN-BC-OBITS] May 31, 2003, Vancouver BC part 1 of 2; http://archiver.rootsweb.ancestry.com/th/read/CAN-BC-OBITS/2003-05/1054408284: “de WOLF, John Anthony St. Etienne passed away peacefully and with dignity at St. Paul’s Hospital, on May 28, 2003. Lovingly remembered by his wife Mary Portelance; children, Daurean (Robert Sloan), John (Lisa), David (Janice) and Gaelan; grandchildren Ty, Meaghan and Brent (B.J.); sister Georgia Macrae and many relatives and friends. John had a multi-faceted career. After serving as a Special Advisor to the Minister of Finance in Ottawa, he pursued a career in financial/economic journalism. He was active in reviving the Progressive Conservative Party in B.C. and served as Leader. Subsequently, John served as a policy advisor/consultant to several B.C. governments while pursuing an independent economic consultancy. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, June 4, 2003 at 10:00 a.m. from the First Memorial Funeral Chapel (Boal Chapel), 1505 Lillooet Road, North Vancouver, B.C. (exit 22). In lieu of flowers donations may be made in John’s memory to the B.C. Transplant Foundation c/o Heart Transplant.”

Captain Christopher Arthur Mohun Cator M C
